article.title: Ultimate position resolution of pixel clusters with binary readout for particle tracking

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1(b) shows the actual distribution of track positions for single hit clusters in a pixel sensor. Why does this distribution differ from the commonly assumed distribution in Figure 1(a)?
choices: The actual distribution takes into account charge sharing between pixels, which is related to sensor thickness.
The assumed distribution is only valid for very high energy particles.
The actual distribution includes the effects of noise and crosstalk.
The assumed distribution is based on an outdated model of charge deposition.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2, what do dx and dy represent?
choices: The size of the pixel in the x and y directions.
The drift distance of charge carriers in the x and y directions.
The difference between the true and estimated particle entrance points projected onto the sensor surface.
The uncertainty in the particle momentum in the x and y directions.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 4, what is the relationship between the probability of the most frequent cluster shape (left) and the optimal y position resolution (right)?
choices: There is no relationship between the two.
Regions with high probability of the most frequent cluster shape correspond to better position resolution.
Regions with low probability of the most frequent cluster shape correspond to worse position resolution.
Regions with low probability of the most frequent cluster shape correspond to better position resolution.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 depicts two possible MIP trajectories. What is the significance of the different incidence angles represented by the red and black arrows?
choices: The red arrow represents a particle with higher energy than the black arrow.
The black arrow will always produce a cluster with more hit pixels than the red arrow.

The incidence angle of the red arrow will always result in a cluster with a fixed number of pixels, while the black arrow can produce clusters with varying length depending on the horizontal position of incidence.
The red and black arrows represent particles originating from different sources.
